abstracts.cdata!:
The Services Support Project for Comoros
            aims to maintain basic social and economic infrastructure
            for a significant number of disadvantaged communities and
            specific vulnerable groups; and contribute to building the
            basic capacity of communities and local actors to conduct a
            local development process. The success of the outcome of the
            project in terms of maintaining basic social and economic
            services will be measured by (i) number of students who
            attend school in new or rehabilitated project schools and
            classrooms; and (ii) number of persons in subproject areas
            benefiting from a reduction in transport time and cost. With
            respect to building capacity, the project will measure the
            number of communities with development plans meeting
            participatory process criteria. There are four main project
            components along with one for project monitoring and
            evaluation. 1) The Community-based Subprojects component
            finances small-scale social and economic sub-projects
            identified by communities, including classrooms and schools,
            health posts, small scale water supply and sanitation, and
            feeder roads. 2) The Capacity Building component supports
            capacity building and social capital formation for
            communities, related strategic capacity building for civil
            society; and capacity building of the Fund to Support
            Community Development (FADC) and various stakeholders. 3)
            The Health Services component strengthens the technical
            capacity of selected medical personnel through training in
            specialized fields and through acquisition of critical
            medical equipment. 4) The Urban Water Supply component
            includes rehabilitation and extension of water supply in
            five towns, finances capacity building of water management
            committees, and launches information, education and
            communication (IEC) campaigns on water management,
            sanitation and hygiene.
